title: How to Transfer Files from a Phone to a PC or Mac

steps.title: Attach your Android to your computer with the screen unlocked.
steps.content: Attach your Android to your computer with the screen unlocked. Unlock your screen, then connect your Android to your Windows PC using a USB cable. Plug the USB end of your Android charger cable into one of your computer's USB ports, then plug the charger end into your Android. Make sure the USB cable you are using can transfer data, as not all have this feature. Some USB cables that support data transfer have a special "trident" symbol, but unfortunately, not all do.

steps.title: Tap the "Charging this device via USB" notification (or similar) on your Android.
steps.content: Tap the "Charging this device via USB" notification (or similar) on your Android. This opens the "Use USB to" menu. If no option pops up, try swiping down from the top of your screen to see if the notification is hidden. If it's not there, try a different USB port—some Androids (and some cables) will only recognize certain speed ports. [1] X Research source If that doesn't work, try using a different USB cable, and make sure airplane mode is turned off.

steps.title: Tap Transfer Files or File Transfer.
steps.content: Tap Transfer Files or File Transfer . The option you see will vary by device. This opens a file transfer window you can use to pull files from your Android to the PC.

steps.title: Drag files from your Android to your computer.
steps.content: Drag files from your Android to your computer. Once the file transfer window appears, you can drag files from the Android to the desired folder on your computer. You can eject your Android and then unplug it when you're finished. If the file transfer window did not open, continue to the next step.

steps.title: Open File Explorer .
steps.content: Open File Explorer . If you couldn't use the file transfer window, you can transfer files in File Explorer . Press Windows key + E , or click the folder icon in the lower-left side of the Start menu.

steps.title: Navigate to your Android in File Explorer.
steps.content: Navigate to your Android in File Explorer. To do this, click This PC in the left panel, then double-click your Android.

steps.title: Select the file or folder you want to transfer.
steps.content: Select the file or folder you want to transfer. Most Androids require you to open a storage folder (e.g., "Internal") to view the files, but you may also have to open additional folders. Double-click the folders until you find the file you want to transfer. Click a file to select it, or hold down Ctrl to select multiple files. For Androids with removable storage, you'll usually find the bulk of your files in the "SD" or "Removable" folder rather than the "Internal" folder.

steps.title: Copy the file or folder.
steps.content: Copy the file or folder. Press Ctrl + C to copy your selected file(s) or folder(s).

steps.title: Go to the place on your computer where you want to save the copied item(s).
steps.content: Go to the place on your computer where you want to save the copied item(s). In the File Explorer's left-hand sidebar, click a folder on your computer (e.g., "Documents") in which you want to place the copied item(s).

steps.title: Paste the file or folder.
steps.content: Paste the file or folder. Press Ctrl + V to do so. The copied item(s) will appear in the selected folder, though it may take a while for the files to finish copying, depending on their overall size. You can also perform this process in reverse by copying a file or folder from your computer and then pasting it into a folder in your Android's internal storage.

steps.title: Open Phone Link on your Windows 10 or 11 PC.
steps.content: Open Phone Link on your Windows 10 or 11 PC. An easy way to move files from your Android to your Windows PC is to use Phone Link and the Link to Windows mobile app on your Android. To open Phone Link, type phone link into the Windows search bar, then click Phone Link . If prompted, log in to your Microsoft account.

steps.title: Install the Link to Windows app on your Android.
steps.content: Install the Link to Windows app on your Android. To do this, open any web browser on your phone, go to https://www.aka.ms/yourpc , and follow the on-screen instructions to download. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Sign in to the Link to Windows app with your Microsoft account.
steps.content: Sign in to the Link to Windows app with your Microsoft account. Be sure to use the same Microsoft account you used to log in to your Windows PC.

steps.title: On your computer, select "I have the Link to Windows app ready."
steps.content: On your computer, select "I have the Link to Windows app ready." Click the checkbox to do this.

steps.title: Click Pair with QR code.
steps.content: Click Pair with QR code . A QR code will appear on the screen.

steps.title: Scan the QR code with the Link to Windows phone app.
steps.content: Scan the QR code with the Link to Windows phone app. Here's how: On your phone, tap Link your phone and PC. When asked if the QR code is ready, tap Continue' . Give permission for the app to access your camera if requested. Align the QR code in the camera viewfinder to scan. Follow the on-screen instructions and tap Done .

steps.title: On your Android, select the file you want to transfer.
steps.content: On your Android, select the file you want to transfer. To transfer multiple files, you can open your Files or My Files app and select multiple files.

steps.title: Tap the Share button.
steps.content: Tap the Share button. This might look like a triangle with dots at each point, but it may also just say Share . If you're in your file manager app, you may need to tap a menu first.

steps.title: Select Link to Windows – Send to PC.
steps.content: Select Link to Windows – Send to PC . You'll see this option in the system share drawer.

steps.title: Select your Windows PC to share the selected file(s).
steps.content: Select your Windows PC to share the selected file(s). A notification will pop up in Phone Link on your computer, prompting you to open the file once the transfer is complete. Files are saved to your Downloads folder in a subfolder called "Phone Link." [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Turn on your Android's Bluetooth .
steps.content: Turn on your Android's Bluetooth . Swipe down from the top of the screen. If Bluetooth is disabled, tap the Bluetooth icon to enable it now.

steps.title: Turn on your Windows computer's Bluetooth.
steps.content: Turn on your Windows computer's Bluetooth. Open Start and select Settings . Click Devices (Windows 10) or Bluetooth & devices (Windows 11). If the Bluetooth switch is turned off, click it to turn it on. If this switch has "On" written next to it, your computer's Bluetooth is already enabled.

steps.title: Add your Android as a Bluetooth device.
steps.content: Add your Android as a Bluetooth device. Here's how: Click Add Bluetooth or other device (Windows 10) or + Add device' (Windows 11). Select Bluetooth . Select your Android phone and click Pair . If prompted, click Yes to confirm the code.

steps.title: Click the Bluetooth icon.
steps.content: Click the Bluetooth icon. It's a blue icon that should be in the bottom-right corner of your computer's screen, though you may first have to click the ^ icon here to see it.

steps.title: Click Receive a File.
steps.content: Click Receive a File . It's in the pop-up menu. Doing so will open a new window.

steps.title: Find a file that you want to share from your Android.
steps.content: Find a file that you want to share from your Android. This might be a photo or a video, for example. You can use your Android's file manager to browse internal files and those saved to your SD card.

steps.title: Select the file.
steps.content: Select the file. Tap and hold the file to do so. If it's a photo or video, you can instead tap it to open it.

steps.title: Tap the menu button.
steps.content: Tap the menu button. In most cases, this will be a ⋮ or a ⋯ icon, though some Samsung Galaxy phones will have a MORE icon. A drop-down menu should appear.

steps.title: Tap the "Share" option.
steps.content: Tap the "Share" option. This option will vary in appearance and name depending on your Android.

steps.title: Select the "Bluetooth" option.
steps.content: Select the "Bluetooth" option. Again, this option's appearance will vary from Android to Android.

steps.title: Select your computer's name.
steps.content: Select your computer's name. Tap your computer in the menu that appears.

steps.title: Click the confirmation message on your computer.
steps.content: Click the confirmation message on your computer. If prompted to accept or decline the file transfer on your computer, click Yes . Once you verify that you want to accept the file on your computer and indicate a download location, the file should commence transferring to your computer. You can also send files to your Android by clicking Send a File in the Bluetooth pop-up menu, dragging files to transfer into the transfer window, following the on-screen prompts, and then tapping Accept (or similar) on your Android when prompted.

steps.title: Install LocalSend on your Mac and Android.
steps.content: Install LocalSend on your Mac and Android. Transferring files from an Android to a Mac used to require a free program called "Android File Transfer," but this is no longer available. Unfortunately, there is no free way to connect your Android to your Mac for file transfer that works on all models, including M3 Macs. But don't worry—LocalSend is a free alternative that allows you to transfer files from your Android phone to your Mac similar to AirDrop. On your Mac, you'll find LocalSend on the Mac App Store . On your Android, LocalSend is free on the Play Store .

steps.title: Connect your Android and Mac to the same Wi-Fi network.
steps.content: Connect your Android and Mac to the same Wi-Fi network. Your computer and phone must be on the same Wi-Fi network to transfer files with LocalSend.

steps.title: Open LocalSend on your Android and tap the Send tab.
steps.content: Open LocalSend on your Android and tap the Send tab. This allows you to browse your Android for files to move to your Mac.

steps.title: Select one or more files.
steps.content: Select one or more files. To add more files, tap + Add . All files to be sent will appear at the top.

steps.title: Open LocalSend on your Mac.
steps.content: Open LocalSend on your Mac. Once LocalSend is open on both devices, your Mac should appear in the "Nearby devices" list on your Android. LocalSend gives every device random names like "Wacky Cucumber" and "Bold Elephant," so don't be alarmed.

steps.title: Select your Mac in LocalSend.
steps.content: Select your Mac in LocalSend. Once you do this, you'll be prompted to accept the files on your Mac.

steps.title: Follow the on-screen instructions on your Mac to receive the selected files.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen instructions on your Mac to receive the selected files. The files you transferred from your phone will be available in your Mac's default download folder.

steps.title: Enable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth on your iPhone and Mac.
steps.content: Enable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth on your iPhone and Mac. AirDrop makes transferring files from your iPhone to your Mac easy. You'll just need to make sure your devices are within 30 feet of one another, and both have Bluetooth and Wi-Fi turned on. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on AirDrop on your Mac.
steps.content: Turn on AirDrop on your Mac. To receive files from your iPhone on your Mac, you must enable AirDrop. Click the Control Center icon (the two switches) in your Mac's menu bar, then click the AirDrop icon—it looks like a circle with multiple curved open circles radiating from it—so it turns blue. This should automatically enable AirDrop receiving to make your Mac discoverable. To double-check, click the Go menu, select AirDrop , and select Contacts only or Everyone . [5] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on AirDrop on your iPhone.
steps.content: Turn on AirDrop on your iPhone. Open Control Center by swiping down from the upper-right corner of the screen (or by swiping up if you have an iPhone SE), then tap the AirDrop icon—it looks like a circle with multiple curved open circles radiating from it. When the icon is blue, AirDrop is enabled.

steps.title: Open the file on your iPhone you want to transfer.
steps.content: Open the file on your iPhone you want to transfer. This can be a photo, document, or any other type of shareable file.

steps.title: Tap the sharing icon.
steps.content: Tap the sharing icon. It's the square with an arrow pointing up. On some apps, you may see the AirDrop icon instead, or even the word Share .

steps.title: Tap AirDrop.
steps.content: Tap AirDrop . Nearby devices with AirDrop enabled will appear.

steps.title: Select your Mac and tap Done.
steps.content: Select your Mac and tap Done . A notification will pop up on your Mac.

steps.title: Click Accept on your Mac.
steps.content: Click Accept on your Mac. This transfers the selected file. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Open iTunes on your Windows PC.
steps.content: Open iTunes on your Windows PC. You can easily transfer files from your iPhone to your Windows PC using iTunes, which is available from the Microsoft Store. If you don't have iTunes on your Windows PC, download and install it before proceeding.

steps.title: Attach your iPhone to your computer.
steps.content: Attach your iPhone to your computer. Plug one end of the iPhone's cable into one of your PC's USB ports, and the other into your iPhone. When prompted, tap Allow or Trust on your iPhone's screen.

steps.title: Select your iPhone in iTunes.
steps.content: Select your iPhone in iTunes. Click the iPhone icon at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click File Sharing.
steps.content: Click File Sharing . This option allows you to move files from your iPhone to your computer. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Select the app you want to transfer files from.
steps.content: Select the app you want to transfer files from. You'll see the list of apps in the left panel. Not all apps are supported.

steps.title: Select a file you want to transfer to your PC.
steps.content: Select a file you want to transfer to your PC. You'll see the list on the right.

steps.title: Click Save to and select a location on your computer.
steps.content: Click Save to and select a location on your computer. You can transfer the file to any folder on your computer.

steps.title: Click Save to to transfer the file.
steps.content: Click Save to to transfer the file. This copies the file from your phone to your computer.

steps.title: Open the Google Drive app on your iPhone or Android.
steps.content: Open the Google Drive app on your iPhone or Android. If you want to transfer large files from your phone to your computer, or just want a quick and easy way to wirelessly access files from your phone on any platform, Google Drive is a great cloud-based option. As long as you have a Google account, you can use this method on any device. If you're using an iPhone, you can download Google Drive from the App Store and then log in with your Google account. If you prefer, you can use a different cloud service like Dropbox or iCloud Drive. If you want to use iCloud Drive, point your phone web browser to https://icloud.com/iclouddrive , then log in with your Apple account. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Tap +.
steps.content: Tap + . You'll see this at the bottom-right corner of Google Drive. [9] X Research source If you're using iCloud, tap the cloud icon with an arrow pointing up, then select Choose Files . Alternatively, if you want to transfer photos to your computer, select Photo Library instead.

steps.title: Tap Upload.
steps.content: Tap Upload . This opens a file picker.

steps.title: Select the files you want to upload.
steps.content: Select the files you want to upload. This uploads the files to the cloud.

steps.title: Log in to Google Drive on your computer.
steps.content: Log in to Google Drive on your computer. To do this, point your web browser to https://drive.google.com , click Sign in , and log in with your Google account. If you're using iCloud, log in to https://www.icloud.com with your Apple account, then click Drive .

steps.title: Download the file to your computer.
steps.content: Download the file to your computer. If you uploaded multiple files from your phone to Google Drive, click each file you want to download to select it. Once the files are selected, click the download icon at the top—it looks like an arrow pointing down over a line. Then, when prompted, click Save to save the selected files to your computer.

steps.title: Sync your Contacts data to iCloud.
steps.content: Sync your Contacts data to iCloud. If you want to transfer your iPhone contacts to an email app on your computer, you can do so by exporting them as VCF files, then importing those files into your email app. Start by syncing your phone contacts to iCloud: Open Settings . Tap your name card at the top of the page. Tap iCloud . Tap See All next to "Save to iCloud." Tap the white switch next to "Contacts". If the switch is green, you don't have to tap it.

steps.title: Open the iCloud website.
steps.content: Open the iCloud website. Go to https://www.icloud.com in your web browser. This will open your iCloud dashboard if you're logged in. If you aren't logged in, enter your Apple ID email address and password to log in.

steps.title: Click Contacts.
steps.content: Click Contacts . It's a silhouette of a person. Doing so opens a list of your contacts.

steps.title: Select the contacts you want to export.
steps.content: Select the contacts you want to export. To export all contacts, click All Contacts in the leftmost panel, then click the ••• and select Select All Contacts . a contact. Select any contact in the middle column.

steps.title: Click the Sharing icon .
steps.content: Click the Sharing icon . It's at the top-right corner.

steps.title: Click Export vCard….
steps.content: Click Export vCard… . You'll see it in the pop-up menu. Your contacts' vCard file will download onto your computer. You may have to click Save to download the VCF file.

steps.title: Back up your Android's data
steps.content: Back up your Android's data . Before you can download things like contact information, you need to back up your Android's data to Google Drive. Make sure you do this over an internet connection rather than a cellular data connection.

steps.title: Open Google Drive on your computer.
steps.content: Open Google Drive on your computer. Go to https://drive.google.com/ in your browser. This will open your Google Drive account if you're logged in. If you aren't logged into your Google Drive account, enter your email address and password to proceed. This must be the account to which you backed up your Android. If not, click your initial on the top-right side of the Drive page, click Sign out , and then sign back in with the correct account.

steps.title: Click the number under "Storage" at the bottom-left.
steps.content: Click the number under "Storage" at the bottom-left. The number represents how much space you've used in Google Drive so far.

steps.title: Click the Backups tab and click Download.
steps.content: Click the Backups tab and click Download . You'll see this option in the drop-down menu. Doing so prompts your Android backup to download to your computer. You can now import the VCF file into your email app.
